title: Agentic AI for Clinical Decision Support: Real-Time Diagnosis, Triage, and Treatment Planning
abstract: Clinical decision-making often involves navigating complex data, rapidly changing patient conditions, and the need for precise, context-aware recommendations. Traditional clinical decision support systems (CDSS) provide rule-based assistance but frequently fall short in dynamic environments due to their lack of contextual understanding, adaptability, and real-time responsiveness. In this paper, we introduce an agentic AI framework designed specifically for clinical environments. By integrating autonomous AI agents with medical reasoning capabilities, seamless access to electronic health records (EHRs), and structured inter-agent communication, our system enables real-time diagnosis, triage prioritization, and personalized treatment planning. Using synthetic yet medically realistic patient datasets, we evaluate system performance in terms of diagnostic accuracy, triage precision, interpretability, system latency, and physician satisfaction. The results demonstrate substantial performance gains over traditional systems and lay the groundwork for a new era in clinical AI. The complexity of clinical decision-making continues to grow due to rapidly changing patient data and the demand for timely, context-aware responses. Traditional clinical decision support systems (CDSS) often fall short in dynamic environments. In this paper, we introduce an agentic AI framework that integrates autonomous agents with structured memory and EHR interoperability. The system supports real-time diagnosis, triage, and treatment planning. In comparative evaluations using synthetic patient datasets, our framework achieved 92.4% diagnostic accuracy, 95.2% triage precision, and reduced average response latency to 3.7 seconds—a 40% improvement over rule-based CDSS. The results highlight the transformative potential of agentic AI in augmenting clinical workflows.

INTRODUCTION 
This paper explores how agentic AI —powered by a 
coordinated ensemble of specialized agents —can 
augment human decision -making at every critical 
stage of clinical care: diagnosis, triage, and treatment 
recommendation. We demonstrate how this approach 
not only streamlines decision -making but also fosters 
a symbiotic relationship between humans and 
machines in healthcare. 
 
RELATED WORK  
The field of cli nical decision support has evolved 
significantly over the past two decades. Early systems 
were expert -rule based, drawing on manually 
encoded knowledge bases to recommend actions. IBM 
Watson Health attempted to revolutionize this space 
by incorporating NLP  and statistical reasoning, but 
faced integration challenges and interpretability 
concerns. More recent systems focus on integrating 
machine learning with EHR data, such as Epic's CDS 
hooks and Cerner’s Health Intent platform. 
However, these systems often struggle with 
generalization, dynamic context switching, and inter -
system communication. Agent -based modeling has 
seen growing interest in areas such as epidemiological 
simulation and hospital workflow automation, but its 
application in real-time patient care has been limited. 
Our work bridges this gap by combining the 
robustness of multi -agent coordination with the 
precision of AI-driven clinical reasoning. 
Recent work by Chen et al. (2025) demonstrates the 
ethical and technical foundations for modular, agentic 
systems in healthcare, reinforcing the need for 
transparent reasoning and context -sharing 
mechanisms. Ferber et al. (2024) explore the 
integration of autonomous AI agents for complex 
domains like oncology, showcasing practical 
coordination across age nts with shared memory. 
Golden et al. (2023) provide insights from 
implementing AI in mental health decision support, a 
domain where contextual nuances are critical. These 
studies collectively support the growing consensus 
that agentic paradigms offer a vi able, scalable 
approach to augment human clinicians. 
 
SYSTEM ARCHITECTURE  
Our system is designed around modular, cooperative 
agents, each assigned to a specific task within the 
clinical workflow. The architecture is flexible and 
scalable, enabling seaml ess integration with existing 
hospital information systems. 
Agent Types: 
Intake Agent:  Captures symptoms via structured 
forms and natural language inputs. Uses NLP to 
extract structured data from physician or nurse notes. 
Diagnosis Agent:  Employs decision trees, Bayesian 
networks, and transformer -based models to infer 
potential diagnoses. Uses differential diagnosis 
reasoning to prioritize likelihood. 
Triage Agent: Calculates urgency based on vital signs, 
lab results, and established scoring systems like ES I 
(Emergency Severity Index) and NEWS2 (National 
Early Warning Score).

Coordinator Agent:  Orchestrates workflow, memory

logging.

Memory Integration: 
A memory layer is critical for preserving context. 
Short-term memory (via Redis) holds volatile patient 
data during interaction. Long -term memory (via 
Neo4j) stores structured case histories and decision 
logs, enabling retrospective analysis and patient 
follow-up. Ferber et al. (2024) highlight this need for 
cross-agent memory coherence, especially in domains 
with longitudinal patient data. 
Inter-Agent Communication: 
Agents communicate via the Model Context Protocol 
(MCP) from the OpenAI Agentic SDK. Messages are 
enriched with role -based metadata and patient 
context, ensuring seamless transitions between agents. 
 
 
Tool Integration: 
The system interfaces with a suite of standardized 
APIs and external medical services to enhance its 
diagnostic, triage, and treatment capabilities. It 
utilizes FHIR (Fast Healthcare Interoperability 
Resources) for seamless EHR interoperability, 
allowing agents to retrieve and update patient data in 
real time . For evidence -based reasoning, the system 
employs retrieval -augmented generation (RAG) 
techniques that query medical literature databases 
like PubMed. In addition, it integrates third -party 
clinical tools such as Infermedica, which assist in 
symptom check ing and early -stage differential 
diagnosis. 
Zakka et al. (2023) demonstrated that retrieval -
augmented systems significantly enhance the 
factuality and completeness of clinical responses, 
supporting the relevance of such tools in complex, 
dynamic medical settings.

METHODOLOGY  
4.1 Synthetic Dataset Design 
To rigorously evaluate the agentic AI framework in a 
clinically realistic but controllable setting, we 
constructed a comprehensive synthetic dataset using 
healthcare simulation tools, inspired by public 
resources like MIMIC-III and Synthea. Each synthetic 
patient profile was built to represent a holistic clinical 
picture, including: 
 Demographics: age, gender, ethnicity 
 Presenting complaints and structured symptom 
descriptions 
 Vital signs: temperature, blood pressure, heart 
rate, respiratory rate, oxygen saturation 
 Lab values, imaging summaries, and EHR -like 
physician notes 
 Comorbidities, medication allergies, and current 
medication regimens 
The dataset spans five major diagnostic categories: 
 Respiratory distress 
 Abdominal pain 
 Chest pain 
 Neurological deficits 
 Geriatric polypharmacy cases 
To challenge system adaptabilit y, edge cases were 
introduced with overlapping or ambiguous symptoms 
(e.g., chest pain with gastrointestinal mimicry) and 
atypical presentations in elderly patients. Clinical 
plausibility was reviewed by practicing physicians to 
ensure realism and diversity across cases. 
4.2 Evaluation Process 
The agentic AI system was evaluated through a 
structured, multi-phase benchmarking process: 
1. Case Simulation : Each synthetic profile was 
processed through the full agentic pipeline —
intake, diagnosis, triage, and treatment planning. 
Outputs were logged for physician review. 
2. Expert Review Panel : A panel of three board -
certified clinicians independently scored the 
recommendations for accuracy, safety, and 
clarity. Reviewers were blinded to whether the 
output came fro m the agentic AI or a traditional 
system. 
3. Baseline Comparison : Each case was also run 
through a rules -based CDSS. Metrics were 
compared side-by-side to evaluate improvement. 
4. Stress Testing : Edge cases —such as conflicting 
symptoms or contraindicated medicat ions—were 
used to evaluate robustness.

This hybrid evaluation approach ensured a fair, 
clinical-quality comparison while revealing system 
behavior in nuanced and high-risk scenarios. 
4.3 Metrics Definition 
We defined five core metrics to evaluate system 
performance: 
 Diagnostic Accuracy : Proportion of cases where 
the top-ranked diagnosis matched the physician -
validated gold standard. 
 Triage Precision : Agreement between agent 
triage output and standardized scoring systems 
such as ESI and NEWS2. 
 Treatment Vali dity: Extent to which 
recommended treatments followed institutional 
and global medical guidelines (e.g., NIH, WHO). 
 Latency: Average end-to-end response time from 
input ingestion to treatment recommendation. 
 Physician Satisfaction : Mean Likert -scale score 
(1–5) measuring trust, usability, and perceived 
helpfulness of the system. 
Each metric was calculated over 150 unique cases. For 
quantitative rigor, we computed means, standard 
deviations, and confidence intervals. Statistical 
significance of system differ ences was tested using a 
two-tailed t-test at α = 0.05. 
Golden et al. (2023) emphasized the importance of 
stakeholder trust in AI -based CDS, guiding our 
evaluation framework to include both technical 
performance and physician feedback. 
 
 
 
 
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION  
The agentic AI system outperformed traditional CDSS 
across all metrics. Notably, it demonstrated improved 
adaptability in ambiguous cases and handled 
comorbidity scenarios with greater nuance.

Case Study:  
One illustrative case involved a 56 -year-old male 
presenting with chest pain and shortness of breath. 
The Intake Agent flagged risk factors like smoking 
and obesity. The Diagnosis Agent returned a 
differential including unstable angina, pulmonary 
embolism, and GERD. The Triage Agent assigned a 
Level 2 ESI score. The Treatment Agent pro posed an 
ECG, troponin test, and aspirin initiation —later 
confirmed appropriate by an MD. The system 
completed this cycle in under 4 seconds. 
 
ETHICAL AND REGULATORY CONSIDERATIONS  
AI systems in healthcare must be transparent, 
explainable, and privacy -compliant. Our system 
adheres to HIPAA and supports audit trails for every 
decision made. Each agent logs its decision tree, 
retrieved documents, and confidence levels. In 
ambiguous or low -confidence situations, the 
Coordinator Agent flags the case for human review. 
The importance of auditability and human oversight 
has been echoed in recent work by Chen et al. (2025), 
who advocate for ethical agent governance models 
aligned with real-world accountability standards. This

LIMITATIONS AND FUTURE WORK  
While promising, our system currently assumes high -
quality input data, which may not always be available. 
Real-world deployment will require robust error 
handling and adaptive learning mechanisms. 
 EHR integration varies across institutions and 
may affect interoperability. 
 Expansion to specialties like oncology or 
psychiatry will require new agent skills and 
domain-specific knowledge bases. 
 Future enhancements include: 
o Multimodal reasoning from radiology images 
and genomics 
o Federated learning for privacy -preserving 
model updates 
o Patient-facing conversational agents for 
shared decision-making 
As Lidströmer and Eldar (2022) highlight in their 
analysis of AI responses to COVID -19, future systems 
must also be resilient to emergency settings and 
capable of functioning under limited or rapidly 
evolving data conditions. 
 
CONCLUSION  
Agentic AI offers a compelling ev olution of clinical 
decision support, combining the precision of AI with 
the flexibility of agentic systems. By orchestrating 
collaborative agents around clinical tasks, our 
framework delivers more accurate, efficient, and 
context-aware recommendations. Th is approach not 
only enhances physician workflows but also sets the 
foundation for future intelligent, transparent, and 
ethically aligned healthcare systems.
